content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays three separate tissue sections, which appear to be lymph nodes given their ovoid shape and surrounding adipose tissue. All three nodes look abnormal and highly suspicious for metastasis. They show irregular contours and partial to near-complete replacement of the normal dark basophilic lymphoid tissue with lighter pink and purple areas, suggesting effacement by an infiltrating process.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am examining the first lymph node from the left. I am zooming into this specific area because it highlights the interface between what appears to be residual normal lymphoid tissue (the dense, dark purple area) and a more disorganized, infiltrative-looking region with mixed pink and purple staining. This junction is the most informative location to confirm the presence of metastasis, as it allows for direct comparison between the normal lymphocytes and the potential tumor cells invading the node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the border of the second (central) lymph node. The reason for this specific zoom is to investigate the interface between the lymph node parenchyma and the surrounding pericolic adipose and fibrous tissue. At low power, this border appears blurred and infiltrated, which is highly suspicious for extranodal extension (ENE) of metastatic tumor. ENE is a critical prognostic factor that must be carefully assessed, and it is defined by tumor cells breaching the lymph node capsule and invading the surrounding fat. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the third lymph node from the left. I would zoom into the area indicated by the green box because it shows a distinct, well-demarcated region with a different color and texture from the surrounding lymphoid tissue. At low power, this area appears to contain nests of eosinophilic (pink) cells, which is a classic appearance for metastatic carcinoma deposits within a lymph node. The goal is to confirm the presence of malignant epithelial cells at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view confirms the presence of metastatic carcinoma. On the right, there are sheets of small, dark lymphocytes, which are part of the residual lymph node. Infiltrating from the left and center are nests and poorly formed glands of malignant cells. These tumor cells are much larger than the lymphocytes, with pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear membranes, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is also a significant desmoplastic stromal reaction (the pink fibrous tissue) and areas of necrosis (the granular, acellular debris). This is a definitive positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the right side of the image shows dense lymphoid tissue, confirming this is a lymph node. The left side shows fibrous connective tissue (desmoplasia) and adipose tissue. Critically, there are numerous nests, cords, and single malignant cells infiltrating this fibrous tissue on the left. These cells have large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei and moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The clear presence of tumor cells in the pericapsular fibrous tissue confirms my suspicion. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with definite extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, there are nests of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the normal lymphoid tissue. The malignant cells are large, with pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. They form irregular glands and solid clusters. A key feature is the presence of extensive central comedo-type or "dirty" necrosis (the bright pink acellular material within the tumor nests). This morphology is characteristic of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
